Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Geo-CC&CP Foundry - Building Institutional Capacity for Broadening Participation in the Geoscience Workforce

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many underrepresented minorities attend two year technical and community colleges (2YCs) or minority-serving institutions (MSIs) as undergraduates; but these institutions commonly lack adequate geoscience programs. The purpose of this project is to identify strategies that will help 2YC and MSI institutions to better prepare underrepresented students for geoscience careers. This project brings together partner institutions, individual faculty, educational resource providers, educational researchers, and geoscience employers in a series of focused workshops to determine the systems that would be ideal for increasing geoscience capacity at the targeted institutions. This project directly involves 20 2YC/MSI institutional partners and faculty and 30 additional stakeholders. The main project outcome is a series of reports and related web-based resources for the general geoscience education community outlining challenges and opportunities for improving and expanding geoscience teaching at 2YCs and MSIs.

Lack of access to undergraduate opportunities in two year colleges (2YCs) and minority-serving institutions (MSIs) remains a major barrier to improving the preparation and diversity of the geoscience workforce. The specific goals of this project are to (1) identify and clarify barriers and opportunities for better use of existing instructional resources that engage underrepresented students in the geosciences at 2YCs/MSIs and (2) explore with stakeholders what an ideal model of resources, professional development, and ongoing support for faculty and institutions might look like. These goals are addressed through holding a series of focused stakeholder needs assessments workshops. The needs assessments workshops will yield information about barriers and opportunities by bringing together five key stakeholder groups including (1) instructional faculty at 2YCs and MSIs, (2) educational resource providers, (3) academic chairs and administrators, (4) discipline-based geoscience education researchers, and (5) geoscience workforce employers. Reports and related web-based resources generated during each of these workshops will highlight sustainable institutional infrastructure that will increase access and usability of existing educational resources. Evaluation and project team activities will synthesize findings across the groups to generate knowledge and align future proposals with stakeholder needs. This project focuses activities at the institution and system level, directly involving 20 2YC/MSI institutional partners and faculty, and 30 other individuals from additional stakeholder groups. By working at the system level, it will be possible to ensure that not only individual courses but also pathways to the geosciences are created. The external evaluation will (1) provide an independent, objective view as to how well the project management is functioning as a team, (2) evaluate the extent to which the needs assessment workshops are meeting the project goals, and (3) review stakeholder reports and the project team's final report for accuracy and completeness. The evaluator will be a participant observer in all project team activities and will collect qualitative data from the management team after project management activities via short questionnaires. The evaluator will have access (via the SERC content management system) to all documents and records produced by the management board making it possible to track core project activities and evaluate how the team is progressing. Feedback will be provided at least quarterly to inform the PIs as to where improvements can be made. To complete the second task, the external evaluator will develop and administer a questionnaire about participant satisfaction with the workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The geosciences contribute to the nation’s welfare and economic stability through locating and extracting resources such as minerals and natural gas, through protecting citizens from hazards such as landslides and earthquakes, and through conservation of water and other environmental resources. Projected growth in these geoscience occupations demands a strong, college-educated workforce. Citizens of African American, Hispanic, Native American/Alaskan, and Pacific Islander/Native Hawaiian descent currently make up about 30% of the US population, but only account for about 8% of the geoscience workforce. Tapping into this human capital can allow the US to meet the expected geoscience workforce demands. However, many underrepresented minorities attend two year technical and community colleges (2YCs) or minority-serving institutions (MSIs) as undergraduates, but these institutions commonly lack adequate geoscience programs.

The purpose of this project was to identify strategies that will help 2YC and MSI institutions to better prepare underrepresented students for geoscience careers. To reach this goal, we conducted three major activities. First, we held a series of focus group meetings in August 2015 with key stakeholders – individual faculty and administrators from 2YC and MSI institutions, representatives from geoscience organizations that create and share teaching materials, and researchers specializing in understanding the challenges that minority students face in higher education and in the geosciences. We asked these 40 participants from 34 institutions or organizations to identify the current state of geoscience instruction at 2YCs and MSIs, articulate the desired state, and brainstorm about resources, programs, infrastructure, and other support needed to attain the desired state.

From these meetings, the project team next created a meeting report and website sharing meeting outcomes and action-oriented recommendations to 2YC/MSI faculty, administrators, geoscience professional organizations, education researchers, teaching resource providers, geoscience employers, and funding agencies. These materials articulate steps that could lead to broader participation of minority students in the geosciences. The meeting report and web materials were widely shared among the geoscience community through presentations and professional listservs.

A third and final outcome of this project was professional development for 28 instructors from 2YCs and MSIs with limited prior experience in the geosciences, held at the 2016 Earth Educators Rendezvous. Nineteen participants received support from our project to attend both the project workshop and larger conference. Our workshop was designed to build the capacity of individuals and institutions to offer geoscience courses and programs at 2YCs and MSIs. Each participated designed an action plan showcasing a course, curriculum, program, or outreach effort designed to increase participation in the geoscience among minority students at their institution. These action plans are hosted on the project website as examples of efforts to bring the geosciences to a broad and diverse audience.

Overall this project succeeded in developing a set of print and web-based materials drawn directly from key stakeholders that (1) identify challenges and opportunities for improving and expanding geoscience teaching at 2YCs and MSIs, and (2) share resources and plans of action that can accelerate efforts to prepare underrepresented students for the geoscience workforce. The intellectual merit of this project includes identifying key recommendations from the focus group meetings such as improving alignment between minority student needs and institutional structures, increased use of place-based resources, improved dissemination of “what works” for recruitment and retention of underrepresented students in the geosciences, building trust and personal relationships, and improved marketing of the geosciences as a profession that helps society. The broader impacts include widespread dissemination of project findings and professional development of instructors at 2YC and MSI institutions to improve instruction for underrepresented students.
